articles.headline: Protectors, Too, Gather Profits From ID Theft
articles.snippet: Criminals are not the only ones profiting from identity theft; financial institutions are making money, too.
articles.abstract: Criminals are not the only ones profiting from identity theft; financial institutions are making money, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: Melody Millett was shocked when her car loan company asked her if she was the wife of Abundio Perez, who had applied for 26 credit cards, financed several cars and taken out a home mortgage using a Social Security number belonging to her actual husband.

articles.headline: Objectivity of a Rating Questioned
articles.snippet: Standard & Poor’s made at least 48 changes to a report on a utility company’s financial health, at the company’s request, before releasing the document.
articles.abstract: Standard & Poor’s made at least 48 changes to a report on a utility company’s financial health, at the company’s request, before releasing the document.
articles.lead_paragraph: The three words “uncertain regulatory environment” would not seem that unusual in a public utility rate case.

articles.headline: Shake-Up in Top Tier at Citigroup
articles.snippet: Market Place column; Citigroup shakes up management but not bank's strategy; Robert Druskin, head of corporate and investment bank, in named chief operating officer, filling role that has been vacant since Robert B Willumstad left in July 2005; mo...
articles.abstract: Market Place column; Citigroup shakes up management but not bank's strategy; Robert Druskin, head of corporate and investment bank, in named chief operating officer, filling role that has been vacant since Robert B Willumstad left in July 2005; move appears to signal increased focus on controlling costs, quell internal unrest among Citigroup's top investment bankers, and end speculation that chief financial officer Sallie L Krawcheck will leave soon; chairman-chief executive Charles O Prince II is sticking to his plans: more cross-selling at home, more expansion and investment abroad and improved efficiency; graph (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup investors, who had eagerly been awaiting a management shake-up, got one yesterday. But although the organizational chart will slightly change, it does not mean the bank's strategy will.

articles.headline: Gay and Evangelical, Seeking Paths of Acceptance
articles.snippet: The leaders of gay evangelicals have led the fight against greater acceptance of homosexuals.
articles.abstract: The leaders of gay evangelicals have led the fight against greater acceptance of homosexuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Justin Lee believes that the Virgin birth was real, that there is a heaven and a hell, that salvation comes through Christ alone and that he, the 29-year-old son of Southern Baptists, is an evangelical Christian.

articles.headline: Eastern Europe Struggles to Purge Security Services
articles.snippet: Soviet-era security services are still sending shudders through the region nearly two decades after the fall of the Berlin Wall.
articles.abstract: Soviet-era security services are still sending shudders through the region nearly two decades after the fall of the Berlin Wall.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — Communism is gone and democracy is well implanted in the countries of the old Warsaw Pact, but the Soviet era’s security services are still sending shudders through the region nearly two decades after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

articles.headline: The Cost of an Overheated Planet
articles.snippet: Article in series The Energy Challenge: Fossil Fuel Economics focuses on surge in support in business and politics for cutting emissions of carbon dioxide, main global warming gas; Duke Energy chief executive James E Rogers has emerged as unexpect...
articles.abstract: Article in series The Energy Challenge: Fossil Fuel Economics focuses on surge in support in business and politics for cutting emissions of carbon dioxide, main global warming gas; Duke Energy chief executive James E Rogers has emerged as unexpected advocate of federal regulation that would for first time impose cost for emitting carbon dioxide; Rogers's stance is far from universal within power industry, but it has surprising support, particularly from those, like him, who also produce electricity from carbon-free nuclear reactors; idea to limit fossil fuel emission is beginning to pick up momentum in American politics despite Bush administration's adamant opposition to any limits on such emissions; California has adopted policy aimed at reducing state's contribution to global warming by 25 percent in next 14 years; several influential lawmakers, including Sen John McCain, have introduced legislation intended to limit nation's carbon dioxide output; chart; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: The iconic culprit in global warming is the coal-fired power plant. It burns the dirtiest, most carbon-laden of fuels, and its smokestacks belch millions of tons of carbon dioxide, the main global warming gas.

articles.headline: Before Visit to China, a Rebuke
articles.snippet: Bush administration, in rebuke to China on eve of high-level visit by American officials, formally accuses Chinese leaders of failing to meet commitments to open nation's economy and crack down on piracy of foreign goods; criticism comes in 100-pa...
articles.abstract: Bush administration, in rebuke to China on eve of high-level visit by American officials, formally accuses Chinese leaders of failing to meet commitments to open nation's economy and crack down on piracy of foreign goods; criticism comes in 100-page report to Congress by US trade representative Susan C Schwab; report is required by American law on fifth anniversary of China's joining World Trade Organization; cites continued limits by China on sales of financial services by foreign banks, including credit cards, and limits on some sales of farm goods; also accuses China of engaging in counterfeiting or piracy of software, videos, pharmaceuticals and other goods, sometimes with open encouragement of Chinese officials, and of failing to stiffen punishments on those engaging in these practices; China announces that it will begin to take formal steps to allow foreign banks to offer some retail banking services, like credit cards, and to buy shares in domestic banks; US Treas Sec Henry M Paulson Jr is expected in China on Dec 13; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Tuesday, Dec. 12 - In a rebuke to China on the eve of a high-level visit by American officials, the Bush administration formally accused Chinese leaders on Monday of failing to meet commitments to open the nation's economy and crack down on piracy of foreign goods.

articles.headline: Iraqis Consider Ways to Reduce Power of Cleric
articles.snippet: Several major political parties are in talks to form a coalition to break the influence of the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, Iraqi officials say.
articles.abstract: Several major political parties are in talks to form a coalition to break the influence of the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, Iraqi officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 11 — After discussions with the Bush administration, several of Iraq’s major political parties are in talks to form a coalition whose aim is to break the powerful influence of the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr within the government, senior Iraqi officials say.

articles.headline: Before Visit to China, a Rebuke
articles.snippet: The U.S. formally accused China on Monday of failing to open the nation’s economy and crack down on piracy of foreign goods.
articles.abstract: The U.S. formally accused China on Monday of failing to open the nation’s economy and crack down on piracy of foreign goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING, Tuesday, Dec. 12 — In a rebuke to China on the eve of a high-level visit by American officials, the Bush administration formally accused Chinese leaders on Monday of failing to meet commitments to open the nation’s economy and crack down on piracy of foreign goods.

articles.headline: Objectivity of a Rating Questioned
articles.snippet: Standard & Poor's Corp's credit rating of Portland General Electric is being questioned by customers of Portland General because words 'uncertain regulatory environment' was added to final version of credit agency rating report; most of changes in...
articles.abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp's credit rating of Portland General Electric is being questioned by customers of Portland General because words 'uncertain regulatory environment' was added to final version of credit agency rating report; most of changes in report are revealed in e-mail exchanges between Standard & Poor's analyst Leo Carillo and Kristin Stathis, utility's assistant treasurer; newly disclosed documents open rare window into internal workings of corporate credit rating business; documents raise questions about independence and integrity of rating services, whose reports are relied upon by millions of investors in choosing stocks and bonds; documents show Standard & Poor's solicited comment from utility on draft report and then made at least 48 changes that utility sought before releasing its report on Sept 25; those changes included adding word 'uncertain regulatory environment' and second crucial phrase supporting Portland GE's request to shift all fuel-cost risks off its shareholders and onto customers; utility then used report as independent corroboration of its request to raise rates; officials at S&P, unit of McGraw-Hill, and utility say they did nothing wrong, and credit agency says all changes were made in light of new facts; Oregon documents suggest little has changed since collapse of Enron five years ago; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: The three words "uncertain regulatory environment" would not seem that unusual in a public utility rate case.

articles.headline: Strict U.S. Rules Disqualify Some Canadian Arms Workers
articles.snippet: Arms makers who export to US are in bind, thanks to complex set of State Department rules known as International Traffic in Arms Regulations, or ITAR; unusually strict rules that govern who can work on military projects for US government are in st...
articles.abstract: Arms makers who export to US are in bind, thanks to complex set of State Department rules known as International Traffic in Arms Regulations, or ITAR; unusually strict rules that govern who can work on military projects for US government are in stark conflict with Canadian laws against discrimination; rule that tripped up Marcos Henriquez, who is citizen of El Salvador and Canada and was laid off at General Motors of Canada in 2002, bans nationals of about 20 countries from working on Pentagon contracts or having any access to related plans and materials; not only does it complicate management-employee relations, it makes it hard for American military contractors to bid competitively on Canada's military expansion program, which is worth about $13 billion; General Motors in January will face Ontario Human Rights Tribunal hearing over some of London plant layoffs; that is reminder for GM that to meet State Department rules, foreign-based military contractors often have to break, or at least challenge, local human rights and employment laws (M)

articles.headline: Strict U.S. Rules Disqualify Some Canadian Arms Workers
articles.snippet: Arms makers who export to the U.S. are in a squeeze thanks to a complex set of State Department rules known as the International Traffic in Arms Regulations.
articles.abstract: Arms makers who export to the U.S. are in a squeeze thanks to a complex set of State Department rules known as the International Traffic in Arms Regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA, Dec. 11 — As a private in the Canadian army reserve, Marcos Henriquez drove light armored vehicles, sometimes while he was training with American soldiers.

articles.headline: Shake-Up in Top Tier at Citigroup
articles.snippet: Although the company’s organizational chart will slightly change, it does not mean the bank’s strategy will.
articles.abstract: Although the company’s organizational chart will slightly change, it does not mean the bank’s strategy will.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citigroup investors, who had eagerly been awaiting a management shake-up, got one yesterday. But although the organizational chart will slightly change, it does not mean the bank’s strategy will.

articles.headline: Iraqis Consider Ways to Reduce Power of Cleric
articles.snippet: Several of Iraq's major political parties are discussing forming coalition aimed at diminishing power of radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr within government; two Kurdish groups, most influential Sunni Arab party and Iranian-backed Shiite party...
articles.abstract: Several of Iraq's major political parties are discussing forming coalition aimed at diminishing power of radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr within government; two Kurdish groups, most influential Sunni Arab party and Iranian-backed Shiite party are involved in talks; they have invited Prime Min Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to join them, but Maliki has resisted for fear that parties seek to oust him; US, frustrated with Maliki's political dependence on Sadr, is working to help build new coalition; plan to form political alliance across sectarian lines that isolates Sadr and Sunni Arab extremists carries enormous risks; Sadr could ignite rebellion as he did in 2004; Iraqi officials say other main risk is potential backlash against parties involved in talks; some US commanders say that military assault on Sadr strongholds may be inevitable; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Dec. 11 - After discussions with the Bush administration, several of Iraq's major political parties are in talks to form a coalition whose aim is to break the powerful influence of the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr within the government, senior Iraqi officials say.

articles.headline: In Tuition Game, Popularity Rises With Price
articles.snippet: Many colleges sharply increase tuition to match rival colleges, while also providing more financial assistance; colleges recognize that families associate price with quality, and that tuition rise, coupled with discounts, can lure more applicants ...
articles.abstract: Many colleges sharply increase tuition to match rival colleges, while also providing more financial assistance; colleges recognize that families associate price with quality, and that tuition rise, coupled with discounts, can lure more applicants and revenue; result is price rising faster than inflation but with many consumers paying less than full price; on some campuses, 90 percent of students receive support, from college itself or federal government; some college officials fear that middle and upper middle class could ultimately be squeezed out as tuition rates rise faster than family incomes; biggest expenditure at liberal arts colleges is for salaries and benefits; students also expect many amenities; many colleges with very different endowments and reputations have similar tuition rates because colleges watch each other and set tuition accordingly; graph of tuition and fees (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: COLLEGEVILLE, Pa. - John Strassburger, the president of Ursinus College, a small liberal arts institution here in the eastern Pennsylvania countryside, vividly remembers the day that the chairman of the board of trustees told him the college was losing applicants because of its tuition.
articles.byline: By Jonathan D. Glater and Alan Finder

articles.headline: Eastern Europe Struggles to Purge Security Services
articles.snippet: Renewed effort is under way across former Soviet bloc to expose continued role of Soviet era's security services; some members of secret police remain in place and others are powerful players behind scenes, especially in Bulgaria and Romania; new ...
articles.abstract: Renewed effort is under way across former Soviet bloc to expose continued role of Soviet era's security services; some members of secret police remain in place and others are powerful players behind scenes, especially in Bulgaria and Romania; new governments and pressure from European Union are increasing pressure to root out former secret police; most of Central and Eastern Europe's former Communist countries tried to purge their societies of secret police and informers in aftermath of Communism's collapse, but purges were less effective closer countries were to Russia; in Romania, security services are finally starting to turn over files to National Council, government group checking pasts of government and elected officials, but there is widespread suspicion that most important files are being withheld; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania - Communism is gone and democracy is well implanted in the countries of the old Warsaw Pact, but the Soviet era's security services are still sending shudders through the region nearly two decades after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

articles.headline: The Cost of an Overheated Planet
articles.snippet: It is increasingly clear that there is a considerable cost to carbon dioxide emissions, especially to future generations.
articles.abstract: It is increasingly clear that there is a considerable cost to carbon dioxide emissions, especially to future generations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The iconic culprit in global warming is the coal-fired power plant. It burns the dirtiest, most carbon-laden of fuels, and its smokestacks belch millions of tons of carbon dioxide, the main global warming gas.

articles.headline: Gay and Evangelical, Seeking Paths of Acceptance
articles.snippet: Gay evangelical Christians struggling to reconcile their faith and homosexuality seek to expand definition of evangelical to include them, too; most evangelicals and many gay people consider gay evangelical deluded about their faith; but even when...
articles.abstract: Gay evangelical Christians struggling to reconcile their faith and homosexuality seek to expand definition of evangelical to include them, too; most evangelicals and many gay people consider gay evangelical deluded about their faith; but even when they accept themselves, gay evangelicials often have trouble finding larger community and churches that fit; they have been creating their own organizations where they are accepted; congregations that are open to gay people are often too liberal for evangelicals; evangelical congregations often do not welcome gay members; Web sites have emerged for gay Christians struggling with similar issues; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. - Justin Lee believes that the Virgin birth was real, that there is a heaven and a hell, that salvation comes through Christ alone and that he, the 29-year-old son of Southern Baptists, is an evangelical Christian.

articles.headline: Protectors, Too, Gather Profits From ID Theft
articles.snippet: Fear of identity theft has resulted in billion-dollar business for credit-monitoring services and some say services offer less than they claim; more than 12 million Americans subscribe to credit-monitoring services to alert them to credit activity...
articles.abstract: Fear of identity theft has resulted in billion-dollar business for credit-monitoring services and some say services offer less than they claim; more than 12 million Americans subscribe to credit-monitoring services to alert them to credit activity signaling possible identity theft; biggest beneficiaries from identity theft have been three credit bureaus who offer credit-monitoring services, Equifax, Experian and TransUnion; financial and retail lobbying groups have strongly resisted legislation that could stem fraud from identity theft; consumer advocates caution that people overpay for services when they are legally entitled to one free credit report per year; also, credit monitoring may fail to detect credit activity and alert consumers; cites lawsuit against credit bureau claiming that monitoring services deliver less than promised; photo; chart of credit report sales (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Melody Millett was shocked when her car loan company asked her if she was the wife of Abundio Perez, who had applied for 26 credit cards, financed several cars and taken out a home mortgage using a Social Security number belonging to her actual husband.
